body: please check the travis, and add a few test cases to confirm that it works
Closing this now, but feel free to re-open. I think a callback from Julia side is necessary for this task.

OK, bring in @piiswrong 

I think there is one ways to resolve this issue: modify the CustomOp API so that it contains a callback to notify the finish of the operation. I realized that this is necessary for asynchronize operations.

Specifically, the `Forward`, and `Backward` function will take an argument that is a C style callback API, and the user is able to call the callback when the Forward and Backward operations finishes on the native side
is this PR good to be merged. please squash the commits as in http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/contribute.html#how-to-combine-multiple-commits-into-one

@christallire According to my local testing, the bad GPU-usage is mainly due to my naive implementation of the data-iter in that example. I have opened a PR to fix that and now on my local box, the GPU usage is relatively stable ~ 95% now. Once the PR #1681 is merged, could you please have a test of the latest code on your side? (I'm not sure how the Windows distribution is generated, but in this particular case, since only the example file `lstm_ptb_bucketing.py` is updated, you can just download the latest file and replace your local one).

I have change `mx.symbol.Concat` API in #1682 .

Please wait.
Close this for now. Please feel free to reopen it.

We are tuning CPU performance these days. We are doing it with MxNet.cpp,
though. Will report back if we have some findings.

Without further applying Deep Compression [1] on the SqueezeNet network, the model size reduction compared with the AlexNet is 50x. The proposed Fire module is very similar to a mini version of GoogLeNet's Inception module. Is it possible to compress and accelerate Inception-v4 or Inception-ResNet-v2 using the SqueezeNet method?

[1] S. Han, H. Mao, and W. Dally. Deep compression: Compressing DNNs with pruning, trained quantization and huffman coding. arxiv:1510.00149v3, 2015.

Thank you. Please fix the code style and rebase your branch.
`make` will call this script. See https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/amalgamation/Makefile#L35

Because the mean and var are constants. The backprop to the bottom is even simpler. Since this actually becomes a broadcast multiply and broadcast add. You only need to rescale the gradient by the multiplication factor.

The original gradient is used in the case when the scaling factor is decided by the input(the variance)
please rebase to the most recent master.

can you try with `PS_VERBOSE=1`?

you need to update ps-lite to the newest version first

``` bash
cd ps-lite; git pull; 
```

and then rebuild mxnet

``` bash
make clean; make;
```

the document http://ps-lite.readthedocs.org/en/latest/how_to.html#debug-ps-lite

I haven't carefully tested it, but if we change this line
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/embedding-inl.h#L89
to
Assign(grad_in, req[embedding::kWeight], take_grad(data, grad_out, param_.input_dim));
it seems to do the "addto" behavior as expected.

This means you have not compiled with the GPU enabled version. Check http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/build.html#building-on-ubuntu-debian

You will need to switch USE_CUDA=1 on in the config.mk
Seems was due to the CUDNN operator only support writeTo requirement so far, need to be improved to support addTo as well

closing this issues. If computation overhead is indeed small, then avoid frequent sync makes sense.

Yup, got that part.  Here's my config.mk if there's any obvious error here - 

`
export CC = gcc
export CXX = g++
export NVCC = nvcc

# whether compile with debug

DEBUG = 0

# the additional link flags you want to add

ADD_LDFLAGS = -I /usr/local/cuda-7.0/targets/x86_64-linux/lib/

# the additional compile flags you want to add

ADD_CFLAGS = -I /usr/local/cuda-7.0/targets/x86_64-linux/lib/

#---------------------------------------------

# matrix computation libraries for CPU/GPU

#---------------------------------------------

# whether use CUDA during compile

USE_CUDA = 1

# add the path to CUDA library to link and compile flag

# if you have already add them to environment variable, leave it as NONE

# USE_CUDA_PATH = /usr/local/cuda

USE_CUDA_PATH = /usr/local/cuda

# whether use CuDNN R3 library

USE_CUDNN = 1

# whether use cuda runtime compiling for writing kernels in native language (i.e. Python)

USE_NVRTC = 1

# whether use opencv during compilation

# you can disable it, however, you will not able to use

# imbin iterator

USE_OPENCV = 0

# use openmp for parallelization

USE_OPENMP = 1

# choose the version of blas you want to use

# can be: mkl, blas, atlas, openblas

# in default use atlas for linux while apple for osx

UNAME_S := $(shell uname -s)
ifeq ($(UNAME_S), Darwin)
USE_BLAS = blas
else
USE_BLAS = atlas
endif

# add path to intel library, you may need it for MKL, if you did not add the path

# to environment variable

USE_INTEL_PATH = NONE

# If use MKL, choose static link automatically to allow python wrapper

ifeq ($(USE_BLAS), mkl)
USE_STATIC_MKL = 1
else
USE_STATIC_MKL = NONE
endif

#----------------------------

# distributed computing

#----------------------------

# whether or not to enable multi-machine supporting

USE_DIST_KVSTORE = 0

# whether or not allow to read and write HDFS directly. If yes, then hadoop is

# required

USE_HDFS = 0

# path to libjvm.so. required if USE_HDFS=1

LIBJVM=$(JAVA_HOME)/jre/lib/amd64/server

# whether or not allow to read and write AWS S3 directly. If yes, then

# libcurl4-openssl-dev is required, it can be installed on Ubuntu by

# sudo apt-get install -y libcurl4-openssl-dev

USE_S3 = 0

#----------------------------

# additional operators

#----------------------------

# path to folders containing projects specific operators that you don't want to put in src/operators

EXTRA_OPERATORS =
`

The learning rate of of lr_scheduler isn't initialized correctly. SGD, SGLD, ccSGD and Adam all set it in the following way. The default learning rate is [0.1](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/f74d74d325fcf879dffd6db78a8d54bfc9e06aa6/python/mxnet/lr_scheduler.py#L14).

``` python
if lr_scheduler is not None:
            self.lr_scheduler.base_lr = learning_rate
```
Sorry for my carelessness. I'll make a PR for this.
RMSProp and AdaDelta have the same problem. The common logic should be part of the parent class.
I think it's reasonable to put `clip_gradient` into the parent class, but for the algorithms like AdaDelta, there is actually no idea of `learning_rate`.

it seems that sending data over ib0 is failed. you can double check with it by pull the recent ps-lite, where receiving is also logged.

i also added a `--host-ip` option in the mpi tracker, see https://github.com/dmlc/ps-lite/commit/f2ab107e2d72123d653633e60be2202bd59a5432

if you start your job on gcn8 with ib0, can you add the option `--host-ip 10.202.203.89` and try again?

the problem seems that the scheduler, which uses eth0, is failed to send
data to another machine's ib0 interface.

can you try the `--host-ip` way? namely let the scheduler also use the ib0
interface.

that means zmq is failed to send data on infiniband with the tcp protocol.

can you try `sdp` instead. to use it, you need to hack `ps-lite` a little bit. 
1. go to [ps-lite/src/van.cc](https://github.com/dmlc/ps-lite/blob/master/src/van.cc), then replace the two `tcp:` by `sdp:`. 
2. `make clean; make -j8` on mxnet's root, it should recompile ps-lite

i don't have infiniband at hand, so not sure if the above solution works...

After making the network, I just run this code 

```
logger = mx.metric.logger()

mx.set.seed(1)

model <- 
    mx.model.FeedForward.create(
        softmax, X=training, y=ytrain, eval.data=list(data=testing, label=ytest),
        ctx=mx.cpu(), num.round=200, learning.rate=0.001, momentum=0.9, 
        initializer=mx.init.uniform(0.07), eval.metric=mx.logloss, # wd = 0,
        array.batch.size=100, epoch.end.callback=
            mx.callback.early.stop(8, paste0(model.name,".Fold",i), F, logger), # custom callback func
        batch.end.callback=mx.callback.log.train.metric(100))
```

yes, we'd better shuffle the data every epoch! because here we input the file list to data.py, so we should shuffle the list file `flist`after each epoch, these needs to change some code of data.py(data.py just here is very simple)

Using `add` for `grad_req` means you want the accumulation to be added across different forward-backward pass (e.g. when you implement BPTT manually). For the unrolling case, grad sharing is handled internally automatically since the weights are shared by construction. There is no need to use `add` for `grad_req` in this case.
@pluskid I got it. Thank you so much!

The Stanford CS class CS231n: Convolutional Neural Networks for Visual Recognition compared various optimization algorithms and concluded that "[in practice Adam is currently recommended as the default algorithm to use, and often works slightly better than RMSProp](http://cs231n.github.io/neural-networks-3/#update)". It's definitely worthy to implement Adam in C++.
